Wang Z.-Q. Fetka I. Wagner E.F. Busslinger M. Cell. 1994; 79: 901-912Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (680) Google Scholar). When the Pax5 gene was inactivated in mice by targeted homologous recombination, defects in the midbrain and in B cell lymphopoiesis were observed, including complete abrogation of fetal B lymphopoiesis and incomplete VH gene construction in adult bone marrow (2.Nutt S.L. Urbanek P. Rolink A. Busslinger M. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 476-491Crossref PubMed Scopus (340) Google Scholar). Recent studies have reported that preBI cells from BSAP –/– mice can differentiate in culture or in some cases, in vivo, to a variety of non-B cell types, including macrophages, granulocytes, osteoclasts, T cells, and natural killer cells (3.Nutt S.L. Heavey B. Rolink A.G. Busslinger M. Nature. 1999; 401: 556-562Crossref PubMed Scopus (1) Google Scholar). This suggests a role for BSAP not only in promoting B cell development but also in eliminating other developmental possibilities. Some target genes for BSAP have been identified (reviewed in Ref. 4.Hagman J. Wheat W. Fitzsimmons D. Hodsdon W. Negri J. Dizon F. Curr. Top. Microbiol. Immunol. 2000; 245: 169-194PubMed Google Scholar), including CD19, LEF, N-myc, mb-1, and PD1,although these are unlikely to be critical for B cell development (5.Nutt S.L. Morrison A.M. Dorfler P. Rolink A. Busslinger M. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 2319-2333Crossref PubMed Scopus (261) Google Scholar). BSAP is active later in B cell development, potentially through binding sites in murine heavy (6.Michaelson J.S. Singh M. Birshtein B.K. J. Immunol. 1996; 156: 2349-2351PubMed Google Scholar) and light chain 3′ enhancers (7.Roque M.C. Smith P.A. Blasquez V.C. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 3138-3155Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), J chain, (8.Rinkenberger J.L. Wallin J.J. Johnson K.W. Koshland M.E. Immunity. 1996; 5: 377-386Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar), blk (9.Libermann T.A. Pan Z. Akbarali Y. Hetherington C.J. Boltax J. Yergeau D.A. Zhang D.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 24671-24676Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar), CD72 (10.Ying H. Healy J.I. Goodnow C.C. Parnes J.R. J. Immunol. 1998; 161: 4760-4767PubMed Google Scholar), andRAG-2 promoter (11.Lauring J. Schlissel M.S. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 2601-2612Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). A number of observations suggest that BSAP function can be modulated by its interaction with other proteins. For example, it has been shown that BSAP down-regulates the murine 3′ IgH enhancer hs1,2 in B cell lines in concert with other transcription factors that also bind to this enhancer (12.Singh M. Birshtein B.K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 4392-4397Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). These factors include octamer-binding proteins, κB-binding proteins, and a G-rich DNA-binding protein. Using a GST1 pulldown assay, we detected interaction of BSAP with the POU domains of Oct-1 and Oct-2 (12.Singh M. Birshtein B.K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 4392-4397Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). Other investigators have shown that the DNA-binding domain of BSAP interacts with and recruits Ets family proteins to ternary complexes with the mb-1 promoter in pre-B cells (13.Hagman J. Grosschedl R. Curr. Opin. Immunol. 1994; 6: 222-230Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar). BSAP has also been shown to interact with the acute myeloid leukemia protein, AML, in the regulation of the blk promoter (9.Libermann T.A. Pan Z. Akbarali Y. Hetherington C.J. Boltax J. Yergeau D.A. Zhang D.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 24671-24676Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar) and with PU.1 (14.Maitra S. Atchison M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2000; 20: 1911-1922Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). We have therefore proposed to identify proteins that interact with BSAP using a yeast two-hybrid assay. BSAP is a member of the highly conserved Pax family of transcription factors (recently reviewed in Ref. 15.Mansouri A. Goudreau G. Gruss P. Cancer Res. 1999; 59 (suppl.): 1707s-1710sGoogle Scholar). Like all nine Pax family proteins, BSAP (Pax5) has a highly conserved N-terminal DNA-binding domain, termed the paired box (pax) domain (16.Czerny T. Schaffner G. Busslinger M. Genes Dev. 1993; 7: 2048-2061Crossref PubMed Scopus (353) Google Scholar). The C-terminal region of Pax proteins contains a transcriptional activation domain, and the extreme C-terminal segment of Pax2, Pax5, and Pax8 functions as a repression domain (17.Dorfler P. Busslinger M. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 1971-1982Crossref PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar). Between the paired domain and the transactivation domain is a central domain, which contains a conserved octapeptide motif and varying segments of a homeodomain. The Pax5 subfamily, which includes Pax2, Pax5, and Pax8, contains a partial homeodomain. Although the role of the central domain has not been specifically demonstrated, transient transfection assays of BSAP deletion constructs have implicated the central domain in augmenting the transcriptional activity of BSAP (17.Dorfler P. Busslinger M. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 1971-1982Crossref PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar). Recent data have reported that the partial homeodomain of BSAP interacts with the retinoblastoma protein Rb and the TATA-binding protein TBP (18.Eberhard D. Busslinger M. Cancer Res. 1999; 59 (suppl.): 1716s-1725sGoogle Scholar) Using the central domain of BSAP as a bait in the two-hybrid assay system, we report here a strong interaction with Rch1 (GenBankTM accession number U09559), a protein involved in nuclear import (19.Koepp D.M. Silver P.A. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1998; 1377: M39-M47PubMed Google Scholar). Rch1 is one of several homologous proteins (importin α proteins) that have been implicated in nuclear import of various proteins by interaction with a nuclear localization signal (NLS) (reviewed in Refs. 19.Koepp D.M. Silver P.A. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1998; 1377: M39-M47PubMed Google Scholar and 20.Nakielny S. Dreyfuss G. Cell. 1999; 99: 677-690Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (655) Google Scholar). Human importin α proteins are generally ubiquitously expressed, albeit with some quantitative differences in different tissues (21.Kohler M. Speck C. Christiansen M. Bischoff F.R. Prehn S. Haller H. Gorlich D. Hartmann E. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 7782-7791Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Based on amino acid similarities, human importins have been classified into seven subgroups. Rch1 (also called hSrp1α and karyopherin α2 (KPNA2)) is the single member of subgroup 1, i.e. importin α1, as specified in Refs. 21.Kohler M. Speck C. Christiansen M. Bischoff F.R. Prehn S. Haller H. Gorlich D. Hartmann E. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 7782-7791Crossref PubMed Google Scholar and 22.Welch K. Franke J. Kohler M. Macara I.G. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 8400-8411Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, and pendulin is the mouse homolog of human importin α1. NLS motifs bound by importins are composed of short stretches of highly basic amino acids, some of which are a single stretch of amino acids (i.e. monopartite), others of which comprise two short stretches separated by a spacer region (i.e. bipartite). A general outline of nuclear import has been elucidated. Importin α proteins deliver their cargo into the nucleus through interaction with importin β and movement through the nuclear pore. The importin α-β complex is proposed to dissociate in the nucleus upon binding of Ran GTP to importin β. Importin α then releases its NLS-binding protein and recycles into the cytoplasm through interaction with export proteins. The importin α proteins have a relatively conserved central core of 10 armadillo repeats, each containing ∼42 amino acids, flanked by more diverse N-terminal and C-terminal segments. The crystal structure of importin α proteins has implicated internal armadillo repeats in binding to NLS motifs (23.Conti E. Uy M. Leighton L. Blobel G. Kuriyan J. Cell. 1998; 94: 193-204Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (662) Google Scholar,24.Kobe B. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1999; 6: 388-397Crossref PubMed Scopus (323) Google Scholar). Our observation of an interaction between BSAP and importin α1 has provided the basis for identification of an importin α1 binding site in BSAP, which functions as a nuclear localization signal. Paired domain and central domain segments of other Pax proteins,i.e. quail Pax6 (25.Carriere C. Plaza S. Caboche J. Dozier C. Bailly M. Martin P. Saule S. Cell Growth Differ. 1995; 6: 1531-1540PubMed Google Scholar) and human Pax8 (26.Poleev A. Okladnova O. Musti A.M. Schneider S. Royer-Pokora B. Plachov D. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 860-869Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar), have also been implicated in nuclear localization. However, ours is the first identification of an interaction of a Pax protein with a specific protein involved in nuclear import. Interestingly, the region of importin α1 that binds to the BSAP NLS is a C-terminal segment characterized by acidic amino acids. Murine BSAP (Pax5) (GenBankTM accession number N97013) (Fig. 1) was generously provided by Stephen Desiderio, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD (27.Zwollo P. Desiderio S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 15310-15317Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The paired domain (aa 1–143), central domain (aa 144–267), and transcriptional activation domain (268–391) of BSAP were individually PCR cloned using EcoRI/SalI sites 3′ of the yeastLexA DNA-binding domain in the his+ plasmid vector pEG202 (originally obtained as a gift from Erica Golemis and now obtainable from CLONTECH, Palo Alto, CA). A cDNA library was prepared from Epstein-Barr virus-transformed human peripheral lymphocytes (B cells). This library was shifted via a phage lambda intermediate into the yeast plasmid vector, pACT1 (leu+), 3′ of the GAL-4 activation domain (28.Durfee T. Becherer K. Chen P.L. Yeh S.H. Yang Y. Kilburn A.E. Lee W.H. Elledge S.J. Genes Dev. 1993; 7: 555-569Crossref PubMed Scopus (1300) Google Scholar). The library (a gift of Steven Elledge, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX) was transformed into the ura+ yeast strain CTY 10−5d (MATa ade2 trp1–901 leu2–3, 112 his3–200 gal4− gal80−URA3::lexA-lacZ). Yeast cells were made competent using a lithium acetate method (29.Chien C.T. Bartel P.L. Sternglanz R. Fields S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 9578-9582Crossref PubMed Scopus (1224) Google Scholar). Neither the N-terminal paired domain (DNA binding) nor the central domain of BSAP showed autonomous transcriptional activation, and hence both were candidates for detection of protein interactions in the two-hybrid transcriptional activation assay. For the screen reported here, the bait fragment (aa 144–267) is the serine/threonine-rich central domain region of Pax5, which includes a conserved octapeptide (aa 179–186) and partial homeodomain (aa 229–251) (30.Adams B. Dorfler P. Aguzzi A. Kozmik Z. Urbanek P. Maurer-Fogy I. Busslinger M. Genes Dev. 1992; 6: 1589-1607Crossref PubMed Scopus (468) Google Scholar). There are only three amino acids that differ between full-length mouse and human BSAP (GenBankTMaccession number M96944), none of which are located in the bait used here. The yeast two-hybrid screening procedure was performed essentially as described previously (28.Durfee T. Becherer K. Chen P.L. Yeh S.H. Yang Y. Kilburn A.E. Lee W.H. Elledge S.J. Nature. 1989; 340: 245-246Crossref PubMed Scopus (4880) Google Scholar). Winston F. Gene. 1987; 57: 267-272Crossref PubMed Scopus (2057) Google Scholar). The transformants were grown on M9 (-leu) selective media for 2–3 days to select cDNA library plasmids. Plasmids containing one of each size cDNA from each clone were reassayed by transformation into yeast-competent cells together with one of the following: 1) pEG202 containing the bait; 2) pEG202 without the bait; or 3) pEG202 containing an unrelated cDNA insert shown to interact in a two-hybrid assay with an independent protein. The plasmids that generated blue colonies in the X-Gal filter assay with only the Pax5 bait plasmid were considered for further analysis. Mutation of the NLS motif within full-length BSAP was performed essentially as described in the protocol to the Stratagene (La Jolla, CA) PCR-based site-directed mutagenesis kit. Briefly, to mutate the NLS motif from NKRKRDE to NNRNRDE in the context of full-lengthBSAP, which was previously cloned into theEcoRI/SalI sites of a pEGFP vector (CLONTECH), we used a PCR procedure withPfu polymerase and the following primers (all sequences 5′–3′): GCCGACACCAACAACCGCAACAGGGATGAA and TTCATCCCTGTTGCGGTTGTTGGTGTCGGC. The resulting PCR mixture was treated with DpnI to digest methylated template DNA and used to transform E. coli. The frame and mutations in the newly synthesized pEGFP vector with cloned full-length BSAP were verified by sequencing. In some clones, the NLS motif had only one mutation: NNRKRDE. The central domain of BSAP, containing the singly mutated NLS motif, was PCR-cloned into PCR II using primers pEG-144F and pEG-268R.EcoRI/SalI cleavage released the central domain, which was then cloned into EcoRI/SalI-digested pEG202 vector for subsequent two-hybrid assays. 293T human kidney cells, used for the expression of the GFP fusion proteins, were grown on cover slides in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Mediatech, Cellgro, Herndon, VA), supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 50 units/ml penicillin, and 50 μg/ml streptomycin. 0.5 μg of DNA was transfected into 5 × 105 cells, using the LipofectAMINE reagent and protocol from Life Technologies, Inc. After 12 h, the cells were fixed by 2% paraformaldehyde in phosphate-buffered saline for 15 min, washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline, and mounted in Fluoromount-G. The subcellular location of GFP fusion proteins was determined by fluorescence microscopy Axioskop (Zeiss, Thornwood, NY). We used the yeast two-hybrid assay to identify proteins that interacted with the central domain of BSAP (Fig.1). One million colonies were screened using an X-gal filter assay (31.Fields S. Song O. Nature. 1989; 340: 245-246Crossref PubMed Scopus (4880) Google Scholar). Positive (blue) colonies were candidates for specifying BSAP-interacting proteins. Plasmids containing one of each size library cDNA from each colony were isolated from E. coli and reassayed by transformation into yeast-competent cells together with one of the following: 1) pEG202 containing the bait; 2) pEG202 without the bait; or 3) pEG202 containing an unrelated cDNA insert shown to interact in a two-hybrid assay with an independent protein. The plasmids that generated blue colonies in the X-Gal filter assay with only thePax5 bait plasmid (as shown in Fig.2) were considered for further analysis. Nine different cDNA clones, each uniquely specifying one protein, passed the specificity tests and are currently under investigation. Interestingly, five different cDNAs were found to encode a single protein, i.e. human importin α1 (GenBankTMaccession number U09559). Four of these encoded full-length importin α1, differing only in the length of their 5′ untranslated regions (identified in one colony only for cDNAs beginning at –104, –74, and –62 with respect to the start site of translation and in four separate colonies for the cDNA beginning at –87). The fifth cDNA, which began at nucleotide 732 and encoded the C-terminal half of importin α1, aa 244–529, was identified three times. These data suggested that the central domain of BSAP bound to the C-terminal domain of the nuclear import protein, importin α1. To confirm physical interaction between importin α1 and BSAP, we carried out a GST pulldown assay, using full-length [35S]BSAP translated in vitro and GST fused to full-length pendulin. Mouse pendulin is 97% identical in amino acid sequence to human importin α1. In confirmation of the interaction between BSAP and importin α1 identified in the two-hybrid assay, we found (Fig.3) that BSAP bound to GST-pendulin but did not bind to control GST. The identification of importin α1 as a BSAP-interacting protein implied that interaction might be mediated by a nuclear localization signal in BSAP. We identified a single candidate NLS consensus signal, NKRKRDE, at aa 195–201 in the sequence of the BSAP bait. By assessing deletion mutants of the central domain of BSAP for interaction with importin α1 in the yeast two-hybrid assay, we confirmed that the importin α1 interaction region is localized at the putative NLS, located between aa 195 and aa 201 of BSAP (Fig. 4). Other segments of BSAP, which contained the paired domain (aa 1–143), octapeptide domain (aa 144–194), and partial homeobox domain (aa 202–267), did not bind to importin α1, suggesting that aa 195–201 is the only importin α1 binding site detected in this assay system. Previous studies have shown that mutagenesis of lysine residues within NLS motifs eliminated importin α recognition. We therefore carried out site-specific mutagenesis of the NLS motif within the central domain. Mutation of the NLS at two sites to NNRNRDE in a deletion mutant of the central domain of BSAP eliminated binding of importin αl, and mutation at a single site (to NNRKRDE) within the NLS of the complete central domain of BSAP also eliminated interaction between importin α1 and BSAP in the yeast two-hybrid assay. To assess the functional role of the NKRKRDE amino acid motif, we coupled various segments of the BSAP central domain to GFP (Fig. 5 A). Constructs expressing GFP-BSAP fusion proteins were transfected into 293T human kidney cells, which contain endogenous importin α1 (38.Kohler M. Ansieau S. Prehn S. Leutz A. Haller H. Hartmann E. FEBS Lett. 1997; 417: 104-108Crossref PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar), and intracellular localization was monitored by fluorescence microscopy. Only segments from the central domain that included the NKRKRDE motif were shown to localize predominantly to the nucleus, whereas GFP, by itself, was retained in the cytoplasm (Fig. 5 A). For example (Fig. 5 B), a fusion protein of GFP coupled to aa 144–194 failed to localize to the nucleus, whereas a fusion protein of GFP coupled to aa 144–201, containing an additional seven amino acids comprising the NKRKRDE motif, resulted in predominantly nuclear localization. A highly basic amino acid motif characteristic of an NLS is apparent only in the central domain of BSAP. Accordingly, a GFP-BSAP C-terminal activation domain (aa 255–391) fusion protein, which does not have such a basic motif, failed to enter the nucleus (Fig. 5 A). However, a GFP-BSAP paired domain (aa 16–143) fusion construct localized to the nucleus (Fig. 5 A), despite its apparent lack of an NLS motif and its failure to interact with importin α1, as assessed by the two-hybrid assay (Fig. 3). Deletion of either the N- or C-terminal 10 amino acids from the paired domain showed reduction in nuclear localization of the GFP fusion construct (Fig. 5 A). A similar observation for the paired domain of Pax8 was previously reported (26.Poleev A. Okladnova O. Musti A.M. Schneider S. Royer-Pokora B. Plachov D. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 860-869Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). Hence, both the paired domain and aa 195–201 in the central domain of BSAP confer nuclear localization. We therefore wanted to assess the relative importance of the NLS and the paired domain to nuclear localization of BSAP. A GFP-full-length BSAP fusion protein, in which the NLS motif had been specifically mutagenized, continued to localize predominantly to the nucleus of 293T cells (Fig. 5 A). Nuclear localization was also displayed by GFP fused to a truncation mutant of BSAP, which lacked only the paired domain. Together, these observations suggest that the BSAP molecule has two segments that individually determine nuclear localization. From identification of the various cDNAs encoding importin α1 in the yeast two-hybrid screen (Fig. 2), we predicted that the C-terminal half of importin α1 contained the binding site for BSAP. To further localize the BSAP binding site within importin α1, we generated several deletion mutants of importin α1 for use in the yeast two-hybrid assay. These experiments demonstrated that a C-terminal fragment of importin α1 extending from aa 432 to aa 529 was able to interact with the central domain of BSAP (Fig.6). BSAP is a member of a subfamily of highly homologous Pax genes that includes Pax2 andPax8. Fig. 7 shows that both full-length Pax2 and full-length Pax8 interact with full-length pendulin in a GST pulldown assay. Similarly, we found that other, less closely related Pax proteins, namely Pax3 and Pax6, also interactedin vitro with GST-pendulin. In a yeast two-hybrid screen, we detected interaction of BSAP with several clones encoding importin α1, an NLS-recognizing nuclear transporter. This was the predominant interaction detected in the two-hybrid assay with the central domain of BSAP as a bait. The physical interaction between BSAP and importin α1 was confirmed in GST pulldown assays. The importin α1-interacting NLS was localized within a central domain of BSAP and shown to be functional by conferring nuclear localization to GFP-BSAP fusion proteins. This is the first identification of an interaction of a Pax protein with a specific protein involved in nuclear import. Our experiments show that the paired domain of BSAP can also localize to the nucleus. Because we did not detect binding of the paired domain to importin α1 in the yeast two-hybrid assay, the mechanism by which the paired domain enters the nucleus (whether directly, by interaction with one of the several importin α proteins, or indirectly, via proteins that bind to the paired domain) is not yet known. The paired and central domains of BSAP are redundant in nuclear targeting of BSAP, as site-specific mutagenesis of the NLS in the central domain does not prevent nuclear localization of the full-length BSAP, and a BSAP molecule lacking the paired domain also targets to the nucleus. Paired domain and central domain segments of quail Pax6 (25.Carriere C. Plaza S. Caboche J. Dozier C. Bailly M. Martin P. Saule S. Cell Growth Differ. 1995; 6: 1531-1540PubMed Google Scholar) and human Pax8 (26.Poleev A. Okladnova O. Musti A.M. Schneider S. Royer-Pokora B. Plachov D. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 860-869Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar) have also been implicated in nuclear localization. Intriguingly, an isoform of Caenorhabditis elegans Pax6, which lacks only the paired domain, is regulated in its nuclear entry during development of neuronal cell lineages of the male tail (39.Zhang Y. Henrique F.B. Greenstein D. Chisholm A. Emmons S.A. Mech. Dev. 1998; 78: 179-187Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). Although we have observed that Pax2, Pax8, Pax3, and Pax6 also interact with importin α1 in GST pulldown assays, we have not localized an importin α1 binding site for any Pax protein other than BSAP. It should be noted, however, that both BSAP and importin α1 are highly conserved proteins. Sequence similarities in Pax2, Pax5, and Pax8 raise the possibility that this subfamily shares an importin α1 binding site in the central domain. Based on the general expression of importin α proteins (38.Kohler M. Ansieau S. Prehn S. Leutz A. Haller H. Hartmann E. FEBS Lett. 1997; 417: 104-108Crossref PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar), it is likely that in addition to importin α1, other importin α cDNAs are present in the library from human Epstein-Barr virus-transformed B cells that we screened by the yeast two-hybrid assay. Nonetheless, we detected interaction of BSAP in this assay only with importin α1. Other two-hybrid screens also revealed dominant, if not exclusive, importin α1 interactions with RAG1 (40.Cuomo C.A. Science. 1995; 268: 1049-1053Crossref PubMed Scopus (309) Google Scholar), LEF (42.Prieve M.G. Guttridge K.L. Munguia J.E. Waterman M.L. J. Biol. Virology. 1997; 239: 340-351Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). (Both RAG1 and LEF were also found to bind to a second importin α, α5 (SRP1).) Interestingly, c-Myc, which has a functional NLS, was reported to be unable to bind to importin α1 (Rch1) in a yeast two-hybrid assay (40.Cuomo C.A. Kirch S.A. Gyuris J. Brent R. Oettinger M.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 6156-6160Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar), and Stat1 failed to bind to Rch1 in a GST pulldown assay (45.Sekimoto T. Imamoto N. Nakajima K. Hirano T. Yoneda Y. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 7067-7077Crossref PubMed Scopus (306) Google Scholar). In vitro, many individual importin α proteins can interact with the same NLS (21.Kohler M. Speck C. Christiansen M. Bischoff F.R. Prehn S. Haller H. Gorlich D. Hartmann E. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 7782-7791Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), but when assayed as a mixture of NLS motifs, particular NLS motifs bind preferentially to individual importin α proteins (21.Kohler M. Speck C. Christiansen M. Bischoff F.R. Prehn S. Haller H. Gorlich D. Hartmann E. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 7782-7791Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). These data indicate an apparent selectivity in importin α1 binding to some proteins and raise the possibility that interactions of particular proteins, such as BSAP, with importin α1 might have some specific physiological consequence, either related to or distinct from nuclear import. The crystal structure of yeast importin α bound to the SV40 NLS shows that NLS binding is conferred by two sites, one formed by armadillo repeats 2, 3, and 4 and the second by armadillo repeats 7 and 8 (23.Conti E. Uy M. Leighton L. Blobel G. Kuriyan J. Cell. 1998; 94: 193-204Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (662) Google Scholar). The crystal structure of mouse importin α1 (pendulin) was similarly interpreted (24.Kobe B. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1999; 6: 388-397Crossref PubMed Scopus (323) Google Scholar). Accordingly, internal armadillo repeats of importin α1 (mouse pendulin) and of importin α5 (hSRP1) have been shown to be essential for the binding of LEF (46.Prieve M.G. Guttridge K.L. Munguia J. Waterman M.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 4819-4832Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) and the N-terminal region of RAG1 (47.Cortes P. Ye Z.S. Baltimore D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 7633-7767Crossref PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar), respectively. In contrast, we have found using the yeast two-hybrid assay that the C-terminal 98-amino acid fragment of importin α1, aa 432–529 (containing the last one and a half armadillo repeats, coupled to the C-terminal (non-armadillo) segment of 33 amino acids) binds to BSAP. Previous observations have also reported binding of NLS motifs to the C-terminal segment of importin α. RAG1 (aa 330–1040) was reported to bind to the C-terminal half (aa 244–529) of importin α1 (Rch1) (40.Cuomo C.A. Kirch S.A. Gyuris J. Brent R. Oettinger M.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 6156-6160Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar). (In unpublished data described in Ref. 48.Spanopoulou E. Cortes P. Shih C. Huang C.M. Silver D.P. Svec P. Baltimore D. Immunity. 1995; 3: 715-726Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar, the importin α binding site of RAG1 was limited to the same 98-amino acid fragment of importin α1 that we identified (432–529).) Amino acids 456–538 of importin α5 (hSRP1) were reported to bind to the SV40 NLS coupled to human serum albumin (49.Moroianu J. Blobel G. Radu A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 6572-6576Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar), and aa 475–538 of another member of the importin 5 family, NPI-1, bound to the nonclassical NLS motif of Stat1 (45.Sekimoto T. Imamoto N. Nakajima K. Hirano T. Yoneda Y. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 7067-7077Crossref PubMed Scopus (306) Google Scholar). The crystal structure of importin α indicates that the C-terminal segment is available for protein interactions (23.Conti E. Uy M. Leighton L. Blobel G. Kuriyan J. Cell. 1998; 94: 193-204Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (662) Google Scholar, 24.Kobe B. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1999; 6: 388-397Crossref PubMed Scopus (323) Google Scholar). In fact, the export protein, CAS, has been shown to interact with this region (50.Herold A. Truant R. Wiegand H. Cullen B.R. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 143: 309-318Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar). These observations raise the possibility, as previously suggested for importin α5 (45.Sekimoto T. Imamoto N. Nakajima K. Hirano T. Yoneda Y. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 7067-7077Crossref PubMed Scopus (306) Google Scholar), that importin α1 might engage more than one protein at the same time, potentially serving as a scaffold for assembly of protein complexes. Recent data have shown that components thought to be associated exclusively with nuclear import may play other important roles in cell physiology. For example, importin α-importin β complexes bind to RanGTP, which has now been shown to be associated with mitotic spindle formation (51.Ohba T. Nakamura M. Nishitani H. Nishimoto T. Science. 1999; 284: 1356-1358Crossref PubMed Scopus (253) Google Scholar, 52.Wilde A. Zheng Y. Science. 1999; 284: 1359-1362Crossref PubMed Scopus (325) Google Scholar), and nuclear pore proteins, through which nuclear import occurs, have been implicated in chromatin structure (53.Galy V. Olivo-Marin J.-C. Scherthan H. Doye V. Rascalou N. Nehrbass U. Nature. 2000; 403: 108-112Crossref PubMed Scopus (260) Google Scholar). These data suggest the possibility that the interaction of BSAP with importin α1 may not be exclusively associated with nuclear import. Thomas Meier, Ales Cvekl, and Kalpana Ganjam for their comments on the manuscript; and Dr. Marian Waterman for helpful discussions throughout the course of this work.

Ribonucleotide reductase (RNR) is an essential enzyme in all organisms. It provides precursors for DNA synthesis by reducing all four ribonucleotides to deoxyribonucleotides. The overall activity and the substrate specificity of RNR are allosterically regulated by deoxyribonucleoside triphosphates and ATP, thereby providing balanced dNTP pools. We have characterized the allosteric regulation of the class III RNR from bacteriophage T4. Our results show that the T4 enzyme has a single type of allosteric site to which dGTP, dTTP, dATP, and ATP bind competitively. The dissociation constants are in the micromolar range, except for ATP, which has a dissociation constant in the millimolar range. ATP and dATP are positive effectors for CTP reduction, dGTP is a positive effector for ATP reduction, and dTTP is a positive effector for GTP reduction. dATP is not a general negative allosteric effector. These effects are similar to the allosteric regulation of class Ib and class II RNRs, and to the class Ia RNR of bacteriophage T4, but differ from that of the class III RNRs from the host bacterium Escherichia coli and fromLactococcus lactis.The relative rate of reduction of the four substrates was measured simultaneously in a mixed-substrate assay, which mimics the physiological situation and illustrates the interplay between the different effectors in vivo. Surprisingly, we did not observe any significant UTP reduction under the conditions used. Balancing of the pyrimidine deoxyribonucleotide pools may be achieved via the dCMP deaminase and dCMP hydroxymethylase pathways. Ribonucleotide reductase (RNR) is an essential enzyme in all organisms. It provides precursors for DNA synthesis by reducing all four ribonucleotides to deoxyribonucleotides. The overall activity and the substrate specificity of RNR are allosterically regulated by deoxyribonucleoside triphosphates and ATP, thereby providing balanced dNTP pools. We have characterized the allosteric regulation of the class III RNR from bacteriophage T4. Our results show that the T4 enzyme has a single type of allosteric site to which dGTP, dTTP, dATP, and ATP bind competitively. The dissociation constants are in the micromolar range, except for ATP, which has a dissociation constant in the millimolar range. ATP and dATP are positive effectors for CTP reduction, dGTP is a positive effector for ATP reduction, and dTTP is a positive effector for GTP reduction. dATP is not a general negative allosteric effector. These effects are similar to the allosteric regulation of class Ib and class II RNRs, and to the class Ia RNR of bacteriophage T4, but differ from that of the class III RNRs from the host bacterium Escherichia coli and fromLactococcus lactis. The relative rate of reduction of the four substrates was measured simultaneously in a mixed-substrate assay, which mimics the physiological situation and illustrates the interplay between the different effectors in vivo. Surprisingly, we did not observe any significant UTP reduction under the conditions used. Balancing of the pyrimidine deoxyribonucleotide pools may be achieved via the dCMP deaminase and dCMP hydroxymethylase pathways. ribonucleotide reductase hydroxymethyl Ribonucleotide reductase (RNR)1 catalyzes the reduction of all four ribonucleotides to their corresponding deoxyribonucleotides in all organisms. This is the only de novo way for the cell to make use of the deoxyribonucleotides as building blocks in DNA synthesis (1.Jordan A. Reichard P. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1998; 67: 71-98Crossref PubMed Scopus (626) Google Scholar). Three classes of RNRs are known that differ in quaternary structure and cofactor requirement. Despite these differences, they all catalyze the reduction of ribonucleotides by a related radical-based mechanism (2.Sjöberg B.-M. Struct. Bonding. 1997; 88: 139-173Crossref Google Scholar). All RNRs, except those of herpesviruses (3.Averett D.R. Lubbers C. Elion G.B. Spector T. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 9831-9838Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 4.Averett D.R. Furman P.A. Spector T. J. Virol. 1984; 52: 981-983Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), are allosterically regulated by deoxyribonucleoside triphosphates and ATP, such that DNA precursors are supplied in pools balanced according to the base composition of the different genomes (5.Hendricks S.P. Mathews C.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 2861-2865Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar, 6.Hendricks S.P. Mathews C.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 29512-29518Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). The allosteric regulation of Escherichia coli class Ia RNR has been meticulously characterized by enzyme activity measurements, nucleotide binding, photoaffinity labeling, affinity chromatography, site-directed mutagenesis, and structure determinations (7.Larsson A. Reichard P. J. Biol. Chem. 1966; 241: 2533-2539Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 8.Larsson A. Reichard P. J. Biol. Sjöberg B.-M. Eur. J. Biochem. 1996; 241: 363-367Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar, 14.Eriksson M. Uhlin U. Ramaswamy S. Ekberg M. Regnström K. Sjöberg B.-M. Eklund H. Structure. 1997; 5: 1077-1092Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar). The net result of these findings is that ATP and dATP are positive effectors for reduction of pyrimidine ribonucleotides, whereas dTTP stimulates reduction of guanine ribonucleotides, and dGTP stimulates reduction of adenine ribonucleotides. Apart from this allosteric regulation, which is controlled at the so-called specificity site, class Ia RNRs contain another allosteric site denoted the overall activity site, which binds only ATP or dATP. ATP acts (directly or indirectly) as a positive effector, whereas dATP, which has a lower affinity for the overall activity site than for the specificity site, acts here as a general negative allosteric effector. The nucleotide binding component of class Ia RNRs is a homodimeric protein with four, pairwise identical, allosteric sites. The three-dimensional structure of E. coliclass Ia RNR identifies two identical specificity sites located at the polypeptide interface, and two identical overall activity sites located at the N-terminal domain of each polypeptide (14.Eriksson M. Uhlin U. Ramaswamy S. Ekberg M. Regnström K. Sjöberg B.-M. Eklund H. Structure. 1997; 5: 1077-1092Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar). Several RNRs conform to the allosteric substrate specificity regulation of the class Ia enzymes, whereas hitherto characterized class Ib and class II RNRs lack the overall activity control. The class Ia enzymes from bacteriophage T4 and the parasite Trypanosoma bruceialso lack a general negative overall activity control (15.Berglund O. J. Biol. Chem. 1972; 247: 7276-7281Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 16.Hofer A. Ekanem J.T. Thelander L. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 34098-34104Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). The class III enzyme from E. coli seems most divergent, and has one allosteric site that controls reduction of pyrimidine ribonucleotides and another site that controls reduction of purine ribonucleotides (17.Eliasson R. Pontis E. Sun X. Reichard P. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 26052-26057Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Recently, the allosteric regulation of the class III RNR from Lactococcus lactis was investigated and found to be similar but not identical to that of class III RNR from E. coli (18.Torrents E. Buist G. Liu A. Eliasson R. Kok J. Gibert I. Gräslund A. Reichard P. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 2463-2471Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). The three-dimensional structure of the bacteriophage T4-induced class III RNR was recently solved to high resolution (19.Logan D.T. Andersson J. Sjöberg B.-M. Nordlund P. Science. 1999; 283: 1499-1504Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar). Interestingly, the structures of the T4 class III RNR and the class Ia RNR of the E. coli host have very similar folds and active site regions, whereas the quaternary interactions within the dimers are different (19.Logan D.T. Andersson J. Sjöberg B.-M. Nordlund P. Science. 1999; 283: 1499-1504Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar, 20.Uhlin U. Eklund H. Nature. 1994; 370: 533-539Crossref PubMed Scopus (513) Google Scholar). Because one type of allosteric site is located at the dimer interface and the binding of dATP to these sites is different in the two proteins (14.Eriksson M. Uhlin U. Ramaswamy S. Ekberg M. Regnström K. Sjöberg B.-M. Eklund H. Structure. 1997; 5: 1077-1092Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar, 19.Logan D.T. Andersson J. Sjöberg B.-M. Nordlund P. Science. 1999; 283: 1499-1504Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar), we were anxious to find out whether the apparent differences in mode of allosteric regulation between the well-characterized class Ia RNR and the class III enzymes were related to these structural differences. In this study we have characterized the allosteric regulation of T4 class III RNR, currently the only class III enzyme with a known three-dimensional structure. In comparison to the amino acid sequence of other class III enzymes, and to the known three-dimensional structure of the class Ia enzyme, T4 class III RNR lacks the N-terminal domain. We show that the T4 class III enzyme has only one type of allosteric site, to which the deoxyribonucleoside triphosphates and ATP can bind. Its allosteric regulation differs from those of the E. coli and L. lactis class III enzymes and is similar to the general RNR regulation, in particular that of the class Ib and II enzymes and the class Ia RNR of T4. 3H-Labeled nucleotides were from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech or NEN Life Science products. Assays were stopped after different incubation times by addition of 500 μl of 1 m trichloroacetic acid. The samples were centrifuged at 14,000 rpm for 1 min at 4 °C to precipitate the proteins as pellets. The supernatants were transferred to new tubes, and the nucleotides were extracted with a freon-trioctyl mixture (1,1,2-trichlorotrifluoroethane and trioctylamine in a ratio of 3:1). The extraction was repeated (once or twice) until the pH was >5. Further pH adjustment was made by adding 1 mNH4HCO3, pH 8.9 (final concentration, 50 mm), and 1 m MgCl2 (final concentration, 15 mm). The sample was then loaded onto a boronate affinity chromatography column (Affi-Gel-601 from Bio-Rad) that separates ribonucleotides from deoxyribonucleotides. The buffer was 50 mm NH4HCO3, pH 8.9, 15 mm MgCl2 and the 2-ml flow-through fraction containing the deoxyribonucleotides was collected. A pH adjustment to a value between 2.5 and 3.5 was made with approximately 20 μl of 6m HCl, and the sample was vortexed for 15 s to eliminate CO2. A 1-ml aliquot was loaded immediately onto the high pressure liquid chromatography column (reversed phase C18 column, 4.6 × 125 mm Partisphere SAX-5 from Whatman) and eluted isocratically with phosphate buffer, pH 3.4. Identification of the nucleotide peaks was made by comparing the UV absorption profile with a standard curve, and quantification of the deoxyribonucleotide products was obtained by on-line liquid scintillation counting. Because only the substrates were tritiated and not the effectors, it was easy to distinguish between the added effector deoxyribonucleotides and the formed deoxyribonucleotide products. In addition, binding of dCTP and the substrate ribonucleotides, in the absence and presence of the putative prime positive effector, was far beyond our detection limits. We used competition experiments to test whether dATP, dGTP, and dTTP bound to the same site in NrdD. One nucleotide, dATP, dGTP, or dTTP, was tritiated and used at a fixed concentration, and another unlabeled nucleotide was included at increasing concentrations, starting at the KD value. The results in Fig.2, A–C, clearly show that dATP, dGTP, and dTTP all bind to the same site in NrdD, because they can displace each other in all different combinations. The results fit very well with the individual KD values,e.g. dGTP having the strongest binding constant is also the nucleotide most difficult to displace (Fig. 2 B). We also tested ATP and dCTP as competitors to dATP, dGTP, and dTTP. As shown in Fig. 3, ATP and dCTP were able to compete with dATP but required much higher concentrations than the other nucleotides (Fig. 2, A–C). To determine the KD for ATP, we used the ultrafiltration assay and measured the apparent dissociation constants for dATP, dGTP, or dTTP in the presence of several different concentrations of unlabeled ATP. The apparent KD values were then plotted versus the concentration of ATP (Fig. 4), and from this curve it was possible to extrapolate a KD for ATP of approximately 1.2 mm (Table I). Our standard enzymatic activity assay uses CTP as a substrate. From this assay, it was clear that both ATP and dATP are positive effectors for CTP reduction (TableII). Also seen is that the enzyme has an intrinsic ability to reduce CTP in the absence of a positive allosteric effector. Addition of ATP increased the specific activity of CTP reduction 1.6 times, and addition of dATP doubled the specific activity. Addition of dTTP or dGTP resulted in a drastic decrease of the CTP reduction to 5–10% of the basal, nonregulated CTP reduction (data not shown).Table IICTP activity assayEffectorSpecific activitynmole/min · mgNone370ATP575dATP730 Open table in a new tab To identify prime allosteric effectors for the other substrates, we used the mixed-substrate assay with equal concentrations (1.5 mm) of all nucleoside triphosphates, as described previously (16.Hofer A. Ekanem J.T. Thelander L. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 34098-34104Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). This assay gives a more “in vivo”-like situation in that reduction of all four substrates is monitored simultaneously. The conditions were the same as for the CTP activity assay, except that the effector concentrations were lower (0.2 mm) for technical reasons. Initial experiments were designed to measure substrate reduction in the absence of effector nucleotides. In one set of experiments we included all four substrates; ATP may act both as substrate and as allosteric effector in this case. In another set of experiments we excluded ATP from the substrate mix. When only CTP, GTP, and UTP were included, only CTP was reduced (Table III). This is equivalent to the nonregulated reduction of CTP observed in the CTP activity assay (Table II). When all four substrates were included, the reduction of CTP was approximately twice as high (Table III). A corresponding increase was seen when ATP acted as a positive effector in the CTP activity assay (Table II). Open table in a new tab Bold figures denote prime effector/substrate combinations. When dGTP and dTTP were added as allosteric effectors, the reduction pattern becomes quite complex. As shown in Table III, dGTP is clearly the prime effector for ATP reduction, and dTTP is the prime effector for GTP reduction. However, other substrates are reduced as well but to a lower extent. One interpretation of the results is that dGTP and dTTP are general positive effectors for all substrates, but as can be seen in Table III, this is not the case. No GTP is reduced in the presence of dGTP, and very little CTP is reduced in the presence of dTTP. Instead, we favor the explanation that the in vivo-like conditions permit the deoxyribonucleotide products to act as positive effectors directly when they have been formed. Assays incubated for up to 20 min support this conclusion, as will be shown below. We also tested dUTP as an allosteric effector, although this nucleotide has never been observed to act as an allosteric effector for other RNRs. The results were very similar to those for dTTP, showing that the similarity of the two nucleotides transmits to their allosteric effects on T4 NrdD. When dCTP was added as allosteric effector, both CTP and ATP were reduced (Table III). The positive effect of dCTP on ATP reduction competed with ATP to act as a positive effector for CTP reduction. Surprisingly, we did not detect any significant UTP reduction. There is a very low level of UTP reduction at longer incubation times (0.13–0.26 nmol formed after 20 min) but not to an extent comparable to the other substrates. UTP reduction is often co-regulated with CTP reduction in other RNRs (7.Larsson A. Reichard P. J. Biol. Chem. 1966; 241: 2533-2539Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 15.Berglund O. J. Biol. Chem. 1972; 247: 7276-7281Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 17.Eliasson R. Pontis E. Sun X. Reichard P. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 26052-26057Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We therefore omitted CTP from the substrate mixture, both with and without ATP or dATP as allosteric effector, but neither in the absence of nor in the presence of other effector/substrate combinations did we detect any UTP reduction (data not shown). Further support for our interpretations of the four-substrate assays were obtained in time curve experiments with dGTP, dTTP, or dCTP as effector nucleotide. Fig.5 A shows that use of dGTP as effector initially promoted ATP reduction, whereas the resulting increase of dATP later promoted CTP reduction. After 15 min of incubation CTP reduction dominated over ATP reduction (Fig.5 A). Addition of dTTP resulted initially in GTP reduction (Fig. 5 B). After 5 min of incubation, enough dGTP, which has the lowest KD value of all allosteric effectors, had been formed to promote ATP reduction, and from 10 min onward dATP-promoted CTP reduction dominated (Fig. 5 B). With dCTP as effector nucleotide, the reduction of CTP was rapid and efficient (Fig. 5 C). As discussed earlier, this could represent the nonregulated CTP reduction. Formation of dATP was much slower, and even lower but significant amounts of dGTP were produced. The low reduction of ATP and GTP can probably not be ascribed to dCTP as allosteric effector, because the same pattern was seen when CTP was excluded from the substrate mix (data not shown). Fig. 5 D shows the total amount of deoxyribonucleotides produced in each experiment. More NTPs were reduced with dCTP as effector than with dGTP or dTTP. We have characterized the allosteric regulation of the class III RNR from phage T4, and a summary of the results is shown in Fig.6. The T4 class III NrdD dimer contains two equivalent allosteric nucleotide-binding sites. dATP, and high concentrations of ATP, are positive effectors for CTP reduction, dGTP (and to some extent dCTP) is a positive effector for ATP reduction, and dTTP (and dUTP) is a positive effector for GTP reduction. There is no general negative allosteric effector, and there is a substantial nonregulated reduction of CTP in the absence of allosteric effectors. The KD values for binding of dGTP, dTTP, and dATP to T4 NrdD are in the micromolar range. This is high compared with the corresponding binding constants for class Ia RNR from bacteriophage T4 (25.Berglund O. J. Biol. Chem. 1975; 250: 7450-7455Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and class Ia and III RNRs from the E. coli host bacterium (12.Ormö M. Sjöberg B.-M. Anal. Biochem. 1990; 189: 138-141Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar, 17.Eliasson R. Pontis E. Sun X. Reichard P. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 26052-26057Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The four-substrate assay (5.Hendricks S.P. Mathews C.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 2861-2865Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar, 16.Hofer A. Ekanem J.T. Thelander L. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 34098-34104Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar) was instrumental in demonstrating that the deoxyribonucleotide products start to compete as allosteric effectors as soon as they have formed. In this sense the four-substrate assay mimics an in vivo-like situation, and as demonstrated in this study time curves of the mixed-substrate assay are a facile way of deducing the allosteric regulatory scheme of an RNR. The results also demonstrate that the individual deoxyribonucleotide formation rates fit very well with the KD values for the different effectors, where, e.g. dGTP, which has a much lower KD is less efficiently formed than the other deoxyribonucleotides. The dGTP pool in uninfected E. coli is considerably lower than the other dNTP pools. Upon T4 infection, it is increased relative to the other pools, but is still the least abundant one (26.Mathews C.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1972; 247: 7430-7438Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Even though the dNTP pools in general are lower during anaerobiosis than aerobiosis, in T4-infected as well as uninfected E. coli (26.Mathews C.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1972; 247: 7430-7438Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 27.Lu Q. Zhang X. Almaula N. Mathews C.K. Inouye M. J. Mol. Biol. 1995; 254: 337-341Crossref PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar, 28.Zhang X.L. Lu Q. Inouye M. Mathews C.K. J. Bacteriol. 1996; 178: 4115-4121Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), the KD values obtained by us (Table I) are clearly sufficient considering thein vivo concentration of each putative effector nucleotide. From competition experiments we could conclude that ATP bound weakly (K D≈ 1.2 mm) to the allosteric sites in T4 NrdD. Even though its dissociation constant is orders of magnitude higher than those of the dNTPs, it may still be physiologically relevant, because the in vivo concentration of ATP is close to 3 mm (26.Mathews C.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1972; 247: 7430-7438Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 29.Neuhard J. Nygaard P. Neidhardt F.C. Escherichia coli and Salmonella typhimurium. 1. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1987: 445-473Google Scholar). The effect observed by high concentrations of dCTP, however, may not be physiologically relevant, because T4 genomic DNA contains hydroxymethylcytosine instead of cytosine. Consequently, T4-infected E. coli contains a pool of hydroxymethyl (hm)-dCTP instead of dCTP (30.Greenberg R.G. He P. Hilfinger J. Tseng M.J. Karam J.D. Molecular Biology of Bacteriophage T4. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1994: 14-27Google Scholar). Any formed dCTP is efficiently dephosphorylated by the T4-specific enzyme dCTPase/dUTPase to dCMP, which in turn is the substrate for the T4-specific dCMP hydroxymethylase (30.Greenberg R.G. He P. Hilfinger J. Tseng M.J. Karam J.D. Molecular Biology of Bacteriophage T4. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1994: 14-27Google Scholar). In the four-substrate assay we also observed that dUTP had the same allosteric effects as dTTP (TableIII). Again, this is plausibly not physiologically significant, because both the host cell-encoded enzyme dUTPase and the T4-encoded dCTPase/dUTPase will convert any dUTP to dUMP, to enable subsequent dTTP formation via the thymidylate synthase/kinase pathway (29.Neuhard J. Nygaard P. Neidhardt F.C. Escherichia coli and Salmonella typhimurium. 1. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1987: 445-473Google Scholar, 30.Greenberg R.G. He P. Hilfinger J. Tseng M.J. Karam J.D. Molecular Biology of Bacteriophage T4. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1994: 14-27Google Scholar). Most unexpectedly, we were unable to detect any significant UTP reduction in the four-substrate assays, even when the related substrate CTP was omitted from the mixtures. In the aerobic T4 class Ia ribonucleoside diphosphate reductase, the corresponding substrate UDP has a higher K m than the other NDP substrates, and more than two thirds of the dTTP pool is derived from CDP reduction via the dCMP deaminase and thymidylate synthase pathways (31.Chiu C.S. Ruettinger T. Flanegan J.B. Greenberg G.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1977; 252: 8603-8608Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 32.Mathews C.K. Sinha N.K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1982; 79: 302-306Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar). The enzyme dCMP deaminase is allosterically regulated, positively by dCTP and hm-dCTP, and negatively by dTTP (30.Greenberg R.G. He P. Hilfinger J. Tseng M.J. Karam J.D. Molecular Biology of Bacteriophage T4. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1994: 14-27Google Scholar, 33.Maley F. Maley G.F. Prog. Nucleic Acids Res. Mol. Biol. 1990; 39: 49-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). Likewise, the allosterically regulated enzyme dCMP hydroxymethylase is feedback-regulated by hm-dCMP (30.Greenberg R.G. He P. Hilfinger J. Tseng M.J. Karam J.D. Molecular Biology of Bacteriophage T4. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1994: 14-27Google Scholar, 33.Maley F. Maley G.F. Prog. Nucleic Acids Res. Mol. Biol. 1990; 39: 49-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). It would thus be possible for T4 to balance the relative concentrations of dTTP and hm-dCTP via these allosterically regulated pathways, even in the absence of UTP reduction (cf. Fig. 6). The very efficient CTP reduction, compared with the reduction of GTP and ATP (Fig. 5 B), speaks in favor of this suggestion. At this point we can not, however, exclude that the four-substrate assay lacks a suitable positive allosteric effector for UTP reduction, because, e.g. the allosteric effects of hm-dCTP have not been tested. However, the aerobic T4 class Ia RNR, which is very similar to the T4 class III enzyme in its allosteric behavior, responds the same to hm-dCTP as it does to the allosteric effector dCTP (15.Berglund O. J. Biol. Chem. 1972; 247: 7276-7281Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 25.Berglund O. J. Biol. Chem. 1975; 250: 7450-7455Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The allosteric regulation of T4-induced class III RNR is similar to that of the class Ib RNR from Salmonella typhimurium (34.Eliasson R. Pontis E. Jordan A. Reichard P. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 26582-26587Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar) and the class II enzymes (35.Goulian M. Beck W.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1966; 241: 4233-4242Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 36.Beck W.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1967; 242: 3148-3158Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 37.Chen A.K. Bhan A. Hopper S. Abrams R. Franzen J.S. Biochemistry. 1974; 13: 654-661Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar, 38.Eliasson R. Pontis E. Jordan A. Reichard P. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 7182-7189Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar), i.e. RNRs with only one type of allosteric site (Table IV). This regulation is also seen for the class Ia RNR from phage T4 (15.Berglund O. J. Biol. Chem. 1972; 247: 7276-7281Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar).E. coli NrdD (class III), on the other hand, contains two types of allosteric sites; one site regulates reduction of the pyrimidine substrates (CTP and UTP) and the other reduction of the purine substrates (ATP and GTP) (17.Eliasson R. Pontis E. Sun X. Reichard P. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 26052-26057Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Class Ia enzymes also have two different types of allosteric sites; here one site regulates substrate specificity and another N-terminally located site regulates the overall activity of the enzyme by forming an active enzyme when ATP binds and an inactive enzyme when dATP binds (Table IV). Even though the allosteric regulation appears different for class Ia RNRs and E. coli class III RNR, a combination of sequence comparisons and structural considerations (14.Eriksson M. Uhlin U. Ramaswamy S. Ekberg M. Regnström K. Sjöberg B.-M. Eklund H. Structure. 1997; 5: 1077-1092Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar, 19.Logan D.T. Andersson J. Sjöberg B.-M. Nordlund P. Science. 1999; 283: 1499-1504Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar) suggests that the overall location of the allosteric sites in all three RNR classes are similar. One type of allosteric site (the overall regulatory site in class Ia and the pyrimidine regulatory site in E. coli class III) is located in the N-terminal domain, and the other site (the allosteric specificity site in class Ia and the purine regulatory site in E. coli class III) is located at the dimer interface (Table IV). Class Ib enzymes and class II RNRs use only the allosteric specificity regulation at the dimer interface, and lack the overall activity control mediated by the N-terminal domain. This is achieved either by loss of physiological function of the N-terminal domain (some class II RNRs) or by loss of the N-terminal domain per se (class Ib and some class II RNRs).Table IVComparison of allosteric effects between different RNR classesBinding domainEffector boundType of RNRClass IaClass Ib, II, T4 class Ia, IIIE. coli class IIIN-terminalATPCTP/UTP reduction-aNo binding of allosteric effector or lack of binding siteCTP/UTP reductiondATPGeneral inactivation-aNo binding of allosteric effector or lack of binding siteInactivationDimer interfaceATPCTP/UTP reductionCTP/UTPbT4 class III RNR reduces CTP, but not UTPreduction-aNo binding of allosteric effector or lack of binding sitedATPCTP/UTP reductionCTP/UTPbT4 class III RNR reduces CTP, but not UTP reductionInactivationdTTPGTP reductionGTP reductionGTP reductiondGTPATP reductionATP reductionATP reductiona No binding of allosteric effector or lack of binding siteb T4 class III RNR reduces CTP, but not UTP Open table in a new tab The presence of only one allosteric site in T4 NrdD was expected from sequence and structure comparisons of RNRs showing that the T4 class III RNR lacks the residues corresponding to the N-terminal domain (14.Eriksson M. Uhlin U. Ramaswamy S. Ekberg M. Regnström K. Sjöberg B.-M. Eklund H. Structure. 1997; 5: 1077-1092Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar,19.Logan D.T. Andersson J. Sjöberg B.-M. Nordlund P. Science. 1999; 283: 1499-1504Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar). Also the class Ia RNR from phage T4 lacks negative allosteric control (15.Berglund O. J. Biol. Chem. 1972; 247: 7276-7281Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), even though it comprises a N-terminal domain. It has been suggested that it is advantageous for viruses to encode RNRs that lack negative allosteric control, as this will allow a high dNTP flux to multiple replication forks and promote rapid lytic growth (39.Kreuzer K.N. Morrical S.W. Karam J.D. Molecular Biology of Bacteriophage T4. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D. C.1994: 28-42Google Scholar). At the extreme end are the herpesviruses, whose RNRs lack both negative and positive allosteric regulation (3.Averett D.R. Lubbers C. Elion G.B. Spector T. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 9831-9838Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 4.Averett D.R. Furman P.A. Spector T. J. Virol. 1984; 52: 981-983Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Because the allosteric regulation of L. lactis was recently investigated (18.Torrents E. Buist G. Liu A. Eliasson R. Kok J. Gibert I. Gräslund A. Reichard P. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 2463-2471Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar), three class III RNRs can now be compared. The allosteric regulation for E. coli and L. lactisis similar though not identical, but differs from the phage RNR in that only one type of allosteric binding site is found (two are found forE. coli and L. lactis) and that dATP has a positive effect instead of being a negative inhibitor. The negative effects of dATP binding at the two different sites of the E. coli class III enzyme have not yet been experimentally distinguished from each other. Experiments where one of the sites is mutationally inactivated would be enlightening. Despite the differences between the three class III RNRs investigated so far, the common allosteric balancing of the dNTP pools by RNRs is maintained also by the class III enzymes. We thank Prof. I. Björk for help with derivation of equations for measuring indirect binding constants and Prof. L. Thelander for interest and support concerning the mixed-substrate assay.

The human unc-33-like phosphoprotein (hUlip/CRMP-4) is a member of a family of developmentally regulated genes that are highly expressed in the nervous system. Mutations in theC. elegans unc-33 gene lead to worms with abnormal movements. The hUlip gene encodes a 570-amino acid protein with 98% homology to its murine (Ulip) (Byk, T., Dobransky, T., Cifuentes-Diaz, C., and Sobel, A. (1996) J. Neurosci. 16, 688–701) and rat (CRMP-4) (Wang, L. H., and Strittmatter, S. M. (1996)J. Neurosci. 16, 6197–6207) counterparts (Gaetano, C., Matsuo, T., and Thiele, C. J. (1997) J. Biol. Chem. 272, 12195–12201). The hUlip gene was isolated from a human genomic library. It contains 15 exons, including an exon defined by an anaplastic oligodendroglioma expressed sequence tag, and spans at least 61.7 kilobases. hUlip lacks sequences corresponding to the first six exons found in unc-33. unc-33 exons correspond to homologous hUlip exons as follows: VII to 1 and 2, VIII to 3–9, IX to 10–12, and X to 13 and 14. Using the hUlip clone 1 phage, fluorescence in situ hybridization analysis indicates that the hybridization signal localizes to human chromosome 5q32. Deletion analysis of 5′-flanking sequences delineated the sequences sufficient to express a reporter gene in both neuroblastoma cells and myoblasts. A consensus MyoD/myogenin binding site is located in a region of the downstream promoter that is nearly identical to its mouse homologue. Mutagenesis shows that this conserved MyoD/myogenin site is necessary for full promoter activity in both myoblasts and neuroblastoma cells. Mutagenesis shows that this conserved MyoD/myogenin site is necessary for full promoter activity in both myoblasts and neuroblastoma cells. Full-Text PDF Open Access collapsin response-mediated protein turned after cell division unc-33-like phosphoprotein human Ulip murine Ulip anaplastic oligodendroglioma kilobase(s) base pair(s) sodium chloride sodium citrate Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium polymerase chain reaction expressed sequence tag retinoic acid dihydropyrimidine amidohydrolase-related protein To study the genetics of animal behavior, Caenorhabditus elegans were mutagenized, and mutants were identified that had uncoordinated movements and partial defects in their egg-laying behavior (5.Brenner S. Br. Med. Bull. 1973; 29: 269-271Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar, 6.Brenner S. Genetics. 1973; 77: 71-94Crossref Google Scholar). The unc-33 mutations were unique in that they were associated with alterations in axonal outgrowth and guidance of several classes of neurons yet did not involve any defects in neural cell lineages, numbers, or positioning (7.Hedgecock E.M. Culotti J.G. Thomson J.N. Perkins L.A. Dev. Biol. 1985; 111: 158-170Crossref PubMed Scopus (340) Google Scholar, 8.Hedgecock E.M. Culotti J.G. Hall D.H. Stern B.D. Development. 1987; 100: 365-382Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The gene responsible for this defect encoded a novel intracellular protein,unc-33, that was highly expressed within neuronal processes during early embyrogenesis (1.Li W. Herman R.K. Shaw J.E. Genetics. 1992; 132: 675-689Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The first putative mammalian homologue of unc-33 was identified functionally as a 62-kDa protein, collapsin response-mediated protein (CRMP-62)1 that mediated collapsin signaling (9.Goshima Y. Nakamura F. Strittmatter P. Strittmatter S.M. Nature. 1995; 376: 509-514Crossref PubMed Scopus (641) Google Scholar). During neural development, collapsins participate in axonal pathfinding by stimulating growth cone collapse and preventing neurite extension. The identification of otherunc-33-related genes followed; TOAD-64 (turnedon after cell division) was identified as a 64-kDa protein that was highly expressed in the brain, particularly in the cerebral granular neurons, after cessation of cell proliferation (10.Minturn J.E. Fryer H.J. Geschwind D.H. Hockfield S. J. Neurosci. 1995; 15: 6757-6766Crossref PubMed Google Scholar); Ulip ( u nc-33-likephosphoprotein) (2.Byk T. Dobransky T. Cifuentes-Diaz C. Sobel A. J. Neurosci. 1996; 16: 688-701Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) was identified as a highly expressed anomalous protein in the brain detected by anti-stathmin antibodies; hUlip was identified as an anonymous gene induced during the neuronal differentiation of human neuroblastoma cells (4.Gaetano C. Matsuo T. Thiele C.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 12195-12201Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar); 5,6-dihydropyrimidine amidohydrolase (an enzyme involved in uracil and thymine catabolism) and several genes termed 5,6-dihydropyrimidine amidohydrolase-related proteins (DRP-1–3) (11.Hamajima N. Matsuda K. Sakata S. Tamaki N. Sasaki M. Nonaka M. Gene (Amst.). 1996; 180: 157-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar) were found to be homologous by sequence analysis. A systematic study indicated that there are at least four mammalian homologs of unc-33 (Ulip/hUlip/CRMP-4/DRP-3; Ulip2/CRMP-2/CRMP-62/TOAD-64/DRP-2; CRMP-1; and CRMP-3) that are expressed in distinct yet partially overlapping patterns of expression during the development of the nervous system (3.Wang L.H. Strittmatter S.M. J. Neurosci. 1996; 16: 6197-6207Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). CRMP-1 and Ulip (CRMP-4) have the most restricted pattern of expression, being turned on in E15 and off in P15 rat brain tissue. Ulip/hUlip/CRMP-4/DRP-3 is highly expressed in fetal but not adult neural tissues by in situ analysis and evaluation of total RNA, yet it is not detected at comparable levels in fetal or adult muscle tissue (3.Wang L.H. Strittmatter S.M. J. Neurosci. 1996; 16: 6197-6207Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 4.Gaetano C. Matsuo T. Thiele C.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 12195-12201Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). However, when poly(A)+ Northern blots of normal tissues are examined, Ulip/hUlip/DRP-3/CRMP-4 is detected in newborn rat muscle and in the adult human heart and skeletal muscles (2.Byk T. Dobransky T. Cifuentes-Diaz C. Sobel A. J. Neurosci. 1996; 16: 688-701Crossref PubMed Google Scholar,11.Hamajima N. Matsuda K. Sakata S. Tamaki N. Sasaki M. Nonaka M. Gene (Amst.). 1996; 180: 157-163Crossref PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar). The hUlip protein encodes a 62-kDa protein with no signal sequence, transmembrane domain, or classical protein interaction domains. However, hUlip contains a number of consensus phosphorylation sites that may serve as substrates for signaling molecules such as Cdk, protein kinase C, and proline-directed kinases (4.Gaetano C. Matsuo T. Thiele C.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 12195-12201Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Increases in phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of hUlip and Ulip are detected upon induction of neuritogenesis by retinoids in neuroblastoma cells or by nerve growth factor in PC12 cells (2.Byk T. Dobransky T. Cifuentes-Diaz C. Sobel A. J. Neurosci. 1996; 16: 688-701Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Collapsin-induced neurite retraction is blocked in cells injected with antibodies to CRMP-62 (9.Goshima Y. Nakamura F. Strittmatter P. Strittmatter S.M. Nature. 1995; 376: 509-514Crossref PubMed Scopus (641) Google Scholar), and experiments indicate that CRMP-62 is involved in G protein-mediated transduction of the collapsin signal (9.Goshima Y. Nakamura F. Strittmatter P. Strittmatter S.M. Nature. 1995; 376: 509-514Crossref PubMed Scopus (641) Google Scholar) as well as other non-G protein-dependent effects on neurite extension and growth cone morphology. Functional studies in other tissues have not been evaluated. To evaluate the developmental regulatory mechanism of hUlip, we have isolated the hUlip genomic sequence and studied its structure, chromosomal location, 5′-flanking sequences, and expression. We demonstrate that two promoters exist in the 5′ region of the hUlip gene and that an evolutionarily conserved MyoD/myogenin site is necessary for optimal expression of hUlip in vitro. Two million phage clones from a human leukocyte genomic library in EMBL3 were screened using a 32P-labeled 1.8-kbXhoI–EspI fragment of the hUlip cDNA (4.Gaetano C. Matsuo T. Thiele C.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 12195-12201Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar), which encompasses the entire coding region. Five positive clones were identified, and phage DNA was isolated with a Lambda DNA isolation kit (Qiagen). For the characterization of selected genomic clones, phage DNA was analyzed by restriction endonuclease digestion withEcoRI or BamHI and subjected to Southern blot analysis to identify genomic DNA fragments that hybridized with a32P-labeled hUlip cDNA fragment. These fragments were subcloned into pBluescript SK(−) (Stratagene) and analyzed by restriction endonuclease digestion and sequencing.
